chapter.title: OPAL firmware
chapter.para: The Open Power Abstraction Layer (OPAL) firmware provides a set of abstractions on top of POWER hardware, providing a standard interface for the operating system to perform hardware-specific functions. The implmentation of OPAL firmware is called "skiboot".

section.title: Platform definitions
section.para: Each hardware platform that skiboot supports is described by a "platform file" - a C file that defines a struct platform, using the DECLARE_PLATFORM macro. These board files are located under the platforms/ directory of the skiboot source tree. shows the definition for the Firestone platform, as an example.

example.title: Platform definition for Firestone
example.programlisting: DECLARE_PLATFORM(firestone) = { .name = "Firestone", .probe = firestone_probe, .init = astbmc_init, .pci_get_slot_info = slot_table_get_slot_info, .external_irq = astbmc_ext_irq_serirq_cpld, .cec_power_down = astbmc_ipmi_power_down, .cec_reboot = astbmc_ipmi_reboot, .elog_commit = ipmi_elog_commit, .start_preload_resource = flash_start_preload_resource, .resource_loaded = flash_resource_loaded, .exit = ipmi_wdt_final_reset, .terminate = ipmi_terminate, };

section.para: Although there are a number of platform “hooks” (like .probe, .init and .pci_get_slot_info), most platforms will only need one or two of their own implementations of these hooks, and can use generic definitions for the others. For OpenPOWER platforms, it's likely that you will only need to change the .name and .probe definitions for a new platform.

The .name member of the platform definition (at ) is just a human-readable string, giving the name of the platform. This is used in a few places of firmware log output (and generally isn't visible to the end-user).

The .probe callback (at ) provided by your platform is important; it allows skiboot to detect whether the platform definition matches the hardware that skiboot is running on. A single build of skiboot is compatible with a number of different platforms, so it needs to check each definition to determine which to use. An implementation of a .probe call will return true if the current platform should be used, and false otherwise. shows the probe function for the Firestone platform.

example.title: Platform probe function for firestone

section.para: A probe function will almost always perform a check on the device tree's top-level "compatible" property, to determine if the current hardware matches the platform definition. In , this the firestone_probe function checks whether the device tree's compatible property contains the string ibm,firestone.

section.title: Adding a new platform definition
section.para: During platform bringup, you will need to add a new platform definition to skiboot. This involves adding a new C file under platforms/; for AST-BMC-based machines, use platforms/astbmc/. This file should have a name matching your platform name (for example, firestone.c for the IBM Firestone platform).
There are two platforms that are useful as a reference, as they provide a fairly complete definition of an OpenPOWER platform, and can be used as a base for new platform support. They are:

listitem.para: Palmetto (platforms/astbmc/palmetto.c), a single-socket reference design, used as the original OpenPOWER development platform; and

section.para: You may want to base your new platform on one of these designs, and use the existing platform file as a starting point for OPAL support.

If you do use an existing platform to start your OPAL port, you must change the "compatible" value that is used to identify your hardware. This will involve changing the OPAL_MODEL parameter in the system MRW, and the dt_node_is_compatible() call in your OPAL platform probe function

warning.para: Failing to change the compatible string from a reference-platform identifier will cause your platform to fail OpenPOWER compliance checks.

section.title: PCI slot tables
section.para: Another component of the OPAL platform defintion is the PCI slot tables. These define the physical layout of the PCI bus hardware, and assign names to individual slots (whether or not those slots have a user-accessible connector). These provide human-readable names to the hardware slots, so that slots can be identified by name, and can match names used in any platform documentation.
PCI slot tables are completely optional. However, if a slot table is present, it must be correct.

note.para: A PCI slot table can only be manually verified as correct. If in doubt, disable the slot table.

section.para: shows an example slot-table defintion, describing a PCI host bridge (phb_table), and with two sets of "downstream" ports (slot_table_0 and slot_table_1). Note that each array is terminated by an entry with etype of st_end.

example.title: Simple slot table

section.para: The slot table definitions create a tree-like heirachy of slot definitions. Each definition is a struct slot_table_entry, and has a "type"; one of:

listitem.para: st_phb - for a PCI host bridge,
st_builtin_dev - for a built-in device; and
st_pluggable_slot - for a user-accessible PCI slot.

section.para: Slot definitions of type st_phb must have a children member, which is a pointer to an array of slot_table_entry structures. This creates the tree-like heriachy to match the hardware layout.
